title: ‘Steve Jobs’ a portrait of a genius, warts and all
text:
‘Steve Jobs’ a portrait of a genius, warts and all James Ward , jmward@visaliatimesdelta.com 10:35 a.m. PDT October 21, 2015 Director Danny Boyle and screenwriter Aaron Sorkin do a brilliant job painting an impressionistic portrait of the late Apple co-founder and tech guru Steve Jobs. Michael Fassbender, left, as Steve Jobs, and Seth Rogen as Steve Wozniak, appear in a scene from the film, “Steve Jobs.” (Photo: Universal Pictures) 7 CONNECT 1 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
There’s a strange notion that the super wealthy moguls are better than us ordinary Joes — that somehow by achieving great power and wealth a CEO or a multi-billionaire have some sort of inherent insight in areas outside their field of success. 
One of the chief triumphs of Danny Boyle’s brilliant “Steve Jobs” is that it explodes the “oracle” myth that surrounds the late Apple CEO (Michael Fassbender), the man who helped usher in the new digital information economy. New to DVD: Week of Oct. 20 
If you believe the movie — and by all accounts the film nails the tech titan’s deeply flawed character, if not all of the historic record of his life — Jobs was a visionary in the tech world but a horrible human being. 
Jobs treated just about everyone he encountered — friends, work colleagues, romantic partners and even his own daughter — shabbily, as they were irksome creatures to be barely tolerated and most assuredly could not understand his vision of the future. 
Think about it. If this guy could rationalize treating his own daughter like an interchangeable part, how would Jobs handle a bunch of people in China putting together the iPhone? 
No wonder the iPhone plant had to put up nets around the building to prevent its workers from jumping off the roof. 
Students of history shouldn’t be surprised by that revelation, though. Other epoch-changing business titans were as flawed as Jobs. 
Henry Ford was a virulent anti-Semite. William Randolph Hearst used his mammoth newspaper holdings as a personal piggy bank. And Andrew Carnegie had the blood of the Homestead Strikers on his hands, even as he gave away his vast fortune for admirable public projects. New to streaming: Week of Oct. 20 
Boyle and screenwriter Aaron Sorkin (“The West Wing” and “The Social Network”) construct “Steve Jobs” as a sort of trial. The first half of the film is a prosecutorial brief laying out all of Jobs’ character flaws. The second act of the film is his defense. Boyle and Sorkin leave it up to the audience to deliver their own verdict. 
The film’s story is built around the launching of three different major tech products: The Macintosh, the NEXT computer and the iMac over a 15-year period. At each product launch a series of characters — akin to the ghosts who visit Scrooge in “A Christmas Carol” — come to cajole, lecture and prod the executive. 
Most prominently, there’s Steve Wozniak (Seth Rogen), Jobs’ lifelong friend and co-founder of Apple, John Sculley (Jeff Daniels), his father figure and eventual mortal enemy and Joanna Hoffman (Kate Winslet), his conscience and den mother, of sorts. 
Michael Fassbender, left, as Steve Jobs and Makenzie Moss as a young Lisa Jobs, appear in a scene from the film “Steve Jobs.” (Photo: Universal Pictures) 
Boyle weaves all these characters together brilliantly as they spout Sorkin’s rapid-fire and razor-sharp dialogue. All the actors have their moments to shine as they deliver Sorkin’s brilliant screenplay, which throws verbal darts at the Apple CEO, who mostly deftly deflects criticism with charisma, showmanship and brilliance. 
At the center of the movie is a towering performance by Fassbender, who makes Jobs alternately fascinating, repulsive and inspirational depending on his character’s mood. Spielberg, Hanks cross 'Bridge of Spies' in high style 
Watching Fassbender’s performance, you understand why so many people put up with Jobs. He was a world-class jerk, yes, but Jobs also held out the promise to be part of something that transforms the world. 
What “Steve Jobs” compels you to do is take pause and ask this important question: In this new world of information at your fingertips and the ability to connect with anyone in the world in an instant, is it equally important to be a decent human being? 
★★★★ 
Now playing: Tulare Galaxy 10; Visalia Stadium 10 
MPAA rating : R for language 
Film facts: Stars Michael Fassbender, Kate Winslet, Seth Rogen and Jeff Daniels. Directed by Danny Boyle. 122 minutes. 
BOTTOM LINE : Director Danny Boyle and screenwriter Aaron Sorkin do a brilliant job painting an impressionistic portrait of the late Apple co-founder and tech guru Steve Jobs.
